column9: Description
column18: Material of playground floor (rubber, grass, dirt, sand, concrete, wood chip/mulch, asphalt)

column9: This recently-renovated mini park has great public art and murals on display! There is a children's playground with picnic tables and seating. The park provides two swings and a merry-go-round for children to enjoy. Also, kids can enjoy playing on the mosaic serpent, which shoots water from his tail! There are also many benches and picnic tables to rest, eat lunch, and watch your kids play.

A hilltop park with views of the City (including the famous "Postcard Row"), Alamo Square features many things to do. There is a full tennis court, plenty of walking trails and benches, flower beds, and a dual-level kids' lot that had six swings, three slides and a pair of climbing structures. The upper level is for older kids (age 5-12), while the lower level is for the younger ones (age 2-5). Wheelchair access is available at the gate leading into the upper level.

Blossom Hill Park is located between Shannon Road and Blossom Hill Road east of Blossom Hill School. A fully developed neighborhood park with six lighted tennis courts, a baseball field, playground area and picnic tables, B-B-Q pits, restroom facilities and large lawn areas.

Alta Plaza Park features a playground and a large lawn area, two full tennis courts plus a multipurpose basketball/tennis court. There are plenty of paved walking trails, benches, and views of the City. There is a kids' lot that contains three different play structures, a sand lot, benches, slides and seven swings.

column3: Dorado Way and Alta Vista Dr
San Jose Ave & Sgt John V Young St
column9: This large park, home to the Balboa pool, includes a sand playground with climbing structures, four baseball fields, a soccer stadium, tennis courts, and a picnic area.

column3: B St. & Martin Luther King Way

column9: Located just behind the Bernal Heights Branch Library. A very welcoming playground, Bernal Heights is designed around a few trees that shelter small clusters of benches and picnic tables. The play equipment is in fairly good shape and quite inviting. There are restrooms located at the library itself.

The playground at Moss Beach Park features a pirate boat, a miniature lighthouse, dolphin slides, swings and a tot area. Midcoast residents came together in 2004 and turned what had been a ramshackle collection of donated toys and play structures into a lovingly conceived and imaginative play area for kids of all ages. Consultation was provided by local play experts, i.e. the kids.

Bol Park is a quiet neighborhood park. The play structures are good for all ages. Behind the park is a walking / biking trail that can be used. A unique feature of this park is that on Sunday's donkeys are brought to the park to interact with visitors.
The playground features a baseball diamond, tennis and basketball courts, a sand playground, blacktop with four game squares, and a recreation center.

Located on the beautiful San Francisco Bay, Baylands Park provides over seventy acres of developed parkland offering active recreation, pathways and picnic areas for families and large groups. Baylands Park has a Naturalist theme which is enhanced by the many acres of native grasses, open meadows and wonderful vistas. An additional 105 acres of seasonal wetlands is protected as a Wetlands Preserve providing habitat for plants and wildlife. Baylands Park is a successful joint venture between Santa Clara County which owns the property and the City of Sunnyvale which manages and maintains the Park.The Discovery Play Area will catch your child's imagination. This creative playground is wheelchair-accessible. Play features include climbing structures, see-saw snake, spring toys, sand terraces and talk tubes. Young explorers can find fossil imprints in the archeological dig and follow dinosaur tracks.  Three smaller play areas feature swings, a climbing net and a play town.

This playground has a play structure with a sand pit. There is also a softball field, tennis court, and basketball court. A nice area to take dogs for walks; however, it is not an official "off-leash" area. In addition, there is a clubhouse and rest rooms on site.
A picturesque downtown neighborhood park with a playground, picnic tables, basketball court, and lawn area.

Central Park is located east of the Recreation Center, this 13-acre park is considered Millbrae’s top recreational area. Residents and visitors enjoy using this park for family outings, birthdays, weekend BBQ’s, play, and relaxing. During the summer months Millbrae hosts Concerts in the Park and other various activities bringing numerous people to this beautiful area. You will rarely see this park empty.

Belgatos Park is located off of Blossom Hill Road at the end of Belgatos Road. Limited on site parking is available. Natural woodlands and wildlife abound in this beautiful 17 acre park. The park offers a variety of experiences for hikers, bicyclists, and equestrians on the 2 miles of trails. These trails connect to the Santa Rosa Open Space and the Heintz Open Space. Within the park is a playground, restroom, picnic tables, and lawn areas.

Mission Dolores Park is one of the most popular parks in San Francisco with a local Mission District feeling. The playground has great climbing structures and sand area. Lots of grassy area for picnics. Best during the week as it can be overcrowded with picnickers on the weekends.

Boothbay Park offers 11.2 acres of playground area, a sand volleyball pit, lawn area, a basketball court, four tennis courts, a tiny tot play area, barbecue pits, a small amphitheater seating area, and restroom facilities.The large covered picnic pavilion area is ideal for family or company picnics and accommodates up to 100 people. Interested? Call (650)286-3380 to check availability.

Originally a part of the Dibble Hospital Facilities and purchased in 1948, Burgess Park is one of the first city-owned recreation areas in Menlo Park. Located adjacent to the Civic Center complex, the park provides diverse facilities easily accessible to all Menlo Park residents.

Located in the northwest corner of Burlingame, Cuernavaca Park boasts a spectacular view of the Bay. It has radical elevation changes allowing the park to serve as a major green belt as well as a site for youth baseball and softball games. The children’s playground and basketball court are located at the highest elevation on the site. Park users often pause to view planes landing at the San Francisco airport. Apart from the baseball field the park is designed for casual neighborhood use.

This 20-acre park is known for the mosaic water-snake that winds down a hillside. The park has a children's play area, sand volleyball court, covered picnic area, lighted sports fields, and two tennis courts. The sports fields, tennis courts, picnic area, and a snack shack are available to rent Got a younger child who likes to explore? The playground located at Diablo Vista Park is ideal for kids 4 and under. Affectionately known as "Snake Park," this park's pint-sized climbing structures, bucket swings and large sandy area is perfect for toddlers. The park is divided into three play areas: one with small buildings, one with a climbing structure and slides, and one with swings.The center point of the park is a large tile snake. The snake, topped with fountains and a cement pad, slithers down a hill, offering pint-sized climbers many different paths to explore. Kids who climb the snake will be treated to not only a bird's eye view of the park, but also a few fountains for water play.

Renovated and reopened in 2002, Douglass Playground has an excellent hillside location complete with trees and rock outcroppings on two levels. The lowest level includes a Clubhouse, children's play area, informal lawn areas and tennis courts. The upper level is heavily wooded and contains a baseball field. There are picnic tables, restrooms, and it is quite dog friendly!

Duboce Park features baby swings, play structures for kids and a sand play area. There is also a basketball court. The restrooms are located at the adjacent Harvey Milk Rec Center. The large grass field is a mecca for local dogs.The park is located right next to the Harvey Milk Recreational Center, which offers a wealth of community programs which are free are very inexpensive.

Earl J. Carmichael Park is a large park that contains a baseball field, basketball court, and children's playground. The park itself has a dedicated parking lot. The play area is of older design, being made of wood for all ages and resides on sand. Surrounding the play area are benches for easy child supervision. The park contains picnic tables and BBQs pits. There is one large BBQ located next to the baseball field, but it probably requires reservations.

Everett Alvarez Jr. Park has two at structures, one for the 2-5 and one for the 5-12 age range. The play structures contain numerous slide and climbing structures. The play structures reside on sand and have rubber as well to be handicap accessible. There are numerous big kid and a few little kid swings. The picnic tables overlook the play area, and there is one shared BBQ. The play structure is fenced off from the street but is not fully enclosed. The park has public restrooms and the woman's restroom has a change table.
Glen Canyon Park has hiking trails to explore, plus a rec center with several facilities available to the public: two baseball fields, a tennis court, as well as George Christopher Playground.

Hap Magee Ranch Park (1025 La Gonda Way). Hap Magee has a storied past. A barn façade at the park entrance commemorates the park’s former life as a ranch for longhorn steer. Before the cattle called it home, the site was a summer camp for San Francisco orphans, known as Camp Swain. Look for a drinking fountain commemorating Camp Swain with a plaque and a brick rendering of children playing.Hap Magee’s water feature is a combination of metal tubes that form a tunnel with water spraying inside as kids run through, and water spraying up from the ground. A motion sensor activates the feature on a random circuit. This 17-acre park also has walking trails, separate play areas for younger and older children, picnic areas, and a dog park.

column2: Gordon E. Oliver Eden Shores Park

column9: Henry Schmidt Park has a unique play area. The theme of the play area is the old west and is dedicated towards younger kids, aged 2-5, located on sand. Surrounding the play area are benches so kids can easily be supervised. There are picnic tables tables with individual BBQs throughout the park. The park also contains a tennis court and a baseball diamond.

column2: Central Park, City of San Mateo

column9: With a beautiful waterfront setting, Erckenbrack Park provides 3.4 acres of lawn area, sand beach, a children's playground, and restroom facilities.

This circular park is built on a hill and at the top is a spectacular view. Also at the top is a tennis and basketball court, and a flat ball field. On the side of the hill is a children's playground.

Located at the corner of Juniper and Sagewood streets, is a 5-acre neighborhood park with unique mounded turf areas. Amenities include picnic areas, play apparatus, restrooms, horseshoe pits and plenty of off-street parking.

Montague Park is a huge park that has an attached school. There are a total of 5 play structures in this park. Two belong to the school, but are accessible outside school hours. On one side of the park there is a unique sand play structure near the restrooms. This play struture is semi enclosed and even contains tunnels for kids to use. Youg kids would surely love to utilze this unique and quite large sand pit play structure. There are a number of picnic tables and BBQs overlooking the play structure. At the center of the park, are the two play structures connected to the school. These are dedicated to older kids. At the far end of the park, there are two more play structures. One dedicated to older kids and one to younger kids.

Altamont Creek Park is a 6.9-acre neighborhood park attached to Altamont Creek Elementary School and is closed during school hours. The park offers two medium-sized soccer fields designed for kids 10 and under and accommodates two youth-sized baseball fields. It also offers tot lot equipment, barbecue pits, picnic tables and hiking and biking trails. Park users include Pony Baseball and Livermore Youth Soccer League.

Located on Nob Hill and surrounded by the Grace Cathedral, the Fairmont Hotel, and the Mark Hopkins Hotel, Huntington Park is a quiet place that features a playground for kids, plenty of benches to kick back on, and a nice area for your dogs. There are restrooms available, too.

Osage Station Park is known for its beautiful, memorial rose garden and children's play area with train station.This 35-acre park features four tennis courts, four baseball diamonds, several soccer fields, plus a path around the park. The tennis courts and sports fields can be rented. An additional parking lot is located near the tennis courts, off Orange Blossom Way. The twenty picnic tables and five barbecue pits are located near the children's play area and are available to rent.The park is named after the ranch that grew Osage Oranges, and there are still three Osage Orange trees at the park.

Joe DiMaggio Playground features basketball courts where you can find pick-up games during the week, well-maintained tennis courts and a backboard for solo players to use. Baseball players can enjoy the two fields that are available! Finally, there is a Bocce Ball court if you know the rules of this strategic Italian game.

Locally known as "JK," Julius Kahn is adjacent to the Presidio, the nation's largest urban National Park.The playground is in excellent condition and provides kids and parents two structures to choose from--one designed for babies and toddlers, and another for school-aged kids. Both playgrounds are situated in a sand pit!
Pleasanton’s largest developed park is Pleasanton Sports & Recreation Community Park approximately 103 acres in overall area.

Koret Children's Quarter in Golden Gate Park is one of the oldest, biggest, and best playgrounds in San Francisco - featuring a huge, gloriously terrifying slide down a hillside, an antique carousel, and an amazing climbing structure in which kids can easily get lost (in a good way!)The playground (formerly known as Children's Playground) was originally built in 1887 and is thought to be the nation's first public playground. Koret Children's Quarter reopened in the summer of 2007 after extensive renovations and upgrades.

This park is great if you want to get some fresh air! Four blocks long, the numerous paths allow you to walk or run. There is plenty of open space to play with your child and lots of trees to provide shade on a hot day. Also, its a great place for a picnic! There is a small, fenced in playground for kids, designed by Miller Company Landscape Architects. It is in good condition with two tennis courts. There are picnic tables to sit at and restrooms available.

Come visit Howarth Park, the “jewel" of Santa Rosa. This 152-acre community park provides endless recreational opportunities with a beautiful lake for fishing & boating, a softball field, tennis courts, picnic areas, unique playground structures, miles of hiking and jogging trails, and an amusement area featuring a miniature train ride, carousel, animal farm & pony rides.

This park is great for picnics: company picnics, family reunions, and barbecues! Reservable Picnic Area with Barbecue, Softball/Sports Field, Sand Volleyball Court, Surfaced Basketball Court, Lighted Bocce Courts.

column3: W Santa Clara St & N Autumn St

column9: This 4-acre neighborhood park, is located on Leonard Drive at Williams Street. The park provides neighborhood-oriented facilities, including picnic areas and tennis courts. The park is adjacent to the large open spaces of John Muir School. Amenities include 10 barbecue pits, night lighting, parking, 21 picnic tables, play areas and restrooms.
Located at 3750 Monterey Boulevard, this park offers both picnic and play areas. Green space and a baseball diamond are located on the adjacent school site.

column2: Scotts Valley Tim Brauch Memorial Skate Park

column9: Located at the corner of 20th Street and Vermont in the Potrero Hill neighborhood, McKinley square features a playground with a large sand pit, and a large grassy open area for soccer, football, a game of catch, or to just let the dogs roam. There is a walking trail with benches.

Michelangelo is another nice addition to the Russian Hill area. It is extraordinarily maintained and locals consider it the jewel of the neighborhood. There is a half basketball court, a large tennis backboard to hit on, and a playground with sand area for children. There are benches and picnic tables where you can watch your kids and have lunch. The grass is really nice to sit/lay down on too!

Mission Playground, surrounded mostly by family housing, boasts nearly 100,000 sf of park space. Located off of 19th and Linda streets and bordering on Valencia Street in the Mission District, the park features a clubhouse, outdoor pool with lockers, playground, soccer field, tennis and basketball courts, and open lawn areas.

Moscone Rec offers a plethora of activities for kids and adults. There are four baseball fields and four full tennis courts, two full basketball courts, and a remodeled playground.Dogs are welcome too.There are bathrooms at the rec center and this park also offers two putting greens.

Stafford Grove is the closest playground to Novato's downtown area. The park is equipped with a large playground and benches that are shaded by trees. Stafford Grove is a quaint neighborhood park, which offers a nice break for those shopping with children along Grant Avenue.

Situated next to Mountain Lake where the southern edge of the Presidio meets the Richmond District, this park offers many different amenities. Children enjoy the sand-floor playground at the 12th Avenue entrance that feature slides, swings, and a multi-level play structure. There is a covered picnic/card playing pavilion opposite the 9th Avenue entrance. The great meadow is a favorite place to spend the afternoon for a picnic or to rent for children's birthday parties.

Sycamore Valley Park, located at Holbrook Drive and Camino Tassajara, has a children's play area with popular recreational fountain, a reflection pond with waterfall, and a jogging path that meanders through the park. The picnic area adjacent to the baseball diamonds include eight picnic tables and barbecue pits. In addition, a new group picnic area has been added adjacent to the bocce ball courts that will accommodate up to 65 people.

Thamien Park is a small neighborhood park which contains two play structures. One for older kids and one for younger kids. There are picnic tables overlooking the play structures. The park also has a restroom and it's own dedicated parking lot.

Located next to Stern Grove, Parkside Square is a nice park to visit on a weekend afternoon. There are quite a few amenities that include a walking trail, brand new playground equipment and sand area for children, four tennis courts and a basketball court too; in addition, there is a baseball field, dogs are welcome, and there are clean bathrooms and water fountains available!

column2: Polo Fields at Golden Gate Park
column3: Middle Dr W At Metson Rd

column9: This playground has a unique old west play structure dedicated to toddlers. They'll have a plast playing with the train and the old west buildings.

Portsmouth Square is a community treasure and meeting point. People come here to enjoy their free time and there is something to do for everyone. This is a good central place if you're going to spend time in Chinatown. If you have children, they will enjoy the playground. Checkers/Chess players come here too to enjoy the unique competitive vibe. There is Tai Chi practiced here; however, it is very early in the morning.

A beautiful wooded 4 acre park with a creek, this park is the perfect setting for your wedding, family picnic, or company party. This park offers barbecue and picnic facilities, a children's play area with water feature, two horseshoe pits, a sand volleyball court, restrooms & stage.

In the summer of 2007, the city renovated the lower playground giving kids and families a brand new, large and colorful place to play. There is also a baseball field, two tennis courts, and a basketball court; however, the real treat for the public is the recreation center that is extremely well maintained and has a variety of sports/activities to choose from!There are plenty of picnic tables for lunch, in addition to the BBQ pits, and enough space for your pooch to run around.
Get some lunch from town and picnic in this nice park. New sponge surface is great.

Richmond Playground includes two basketball courts, a tennis court, a large multipurpose court, and a climbing structure with sand pit for children.There is a clubhouse with restrooms.There is a rec center down the street at 251 18th Ave between California and Clement. During the summer there is a day camp for kids and during the fall/school year there are after school and tiny tots programs. Call for more information: (415) 666-7020.

Located in the Richmond District, Rochambeau Playground has a well-kept recreation area that offers two full basketball courts, a tennis court, four-square court, hopscotch blacktops, and a dual-level playground with great climbing structures and sand area. One playground is designed for younger tots and one for older children. There are restrooms at the recreation center and plenty of benches and picnic tables to rest at. The gate closes at 6:00 pm.

Rossi Playground has two baseball fields and a large grass area, three tennis courts, a full basketball court, an indoor pool, and a play area for children. There are two sections of the playground: one is for older kids and one is for younger tots.

St. Mary's Square is great place to visit if you're downtown. Any green space in this area is very valuable to the locals! This place is really gorgeous though. There are lots of trees and bushes, plenty of benches to relax on after a ton of walking, and a play structure if you have kids! There are restrooms available too.

column3: Esplanade Ave and W Beaumont Blvd
Nancy Pelosi Dr & Martin Luther King Jr Dr

column9: This neighborhood park is almost 5 acres and is located at 1245 147th Avenue. A concrete volleyball court and tot lot are also available for use.

Fremont Park has two play structures for both younger and older kids. The playground has an Atlantis type theme incorporating Pegasus statues and sunken dinosaur bones. The playground contains 6 slides, 2 of which are quite large and would be entertaining for big kids. The play structure is located on sand and there is also rubber to make it handicap accessible. There are swings for both tots and big kids. Surrounding the play structure are benches so you can supervise the kids. The park also has three picnic tables overlook the playground and one shared BBQs pit. Note the picnic tables are located on dirt, if you go after a morning shower the area is a little muddy. The park also contains a paved trail that is stroller friendly and can be used when learning to ride a bike.

Frontierland Park is nestled up against the hills of Pacifica with lots of open space and picnic, BBQ, horseshoes and playground amenities. We have one large-group picnic area that can be reserved. Call 650-738-7381 for availability or to make a reservation. We also have several individual picnic tables which are first come, first serve. In the reservable large-group picnic area, we have 10 picnic tables, which seat about 6 to 8 people each. This area also has a counter prep area behind the 2 BBQ pits.

Homeridge Park is a neighborhood park dedicated to older kids, aged 5-12. The wooden play structures are located on sand. The play area is partially enclosed, approximately 80% and is only open where the picnic tables and BBQs are located. This allows for easy supervision of the kids without worry. The park itself also has an open field area for kids to run and play. The park also contains a public restroom.

Jenny Strand Park is located at the end of a cul-du-sac and has a small parking lot. The park has a large grass areas and a small circular play area for kids. The play structure is partially fenced off, on the street side. The play structure is dedicated for younger kids age 0-5 with a wooden play structured residing  on sand. there are two swings, one for big kids and one for little kids. The park has individual bbq pits associate to each picnic table. While you have a clear view of the play structure it is too far away to leave young kids unsupervised.
Stern Grove is the host of the annual Stern Grove Festival. Every Sunday every summer, a music festival is held in the Stern Grove outdoor amphitheater.

Privately built by the South Beach Marina Association, South Beach Park is a lovely location on the waterfront for families and locals. There is a nice little playground for tiny tots with a small sand area and climbing structure appropriate for their ages.There is also lots of grass for kids to run around in.There are benches here to sit down and relax, and this spot is a nice walk to AT&T Park or the Ferry Building.

column3: Voss Ave and S Foothill Blvd

column9: This park is in the heart of the SOMA neighborhood. It has a small playground with recent improvements. It also has a sand pit and some unique climbing structures. There are plenty of paths and picnic tables to enjoy and appreciate your surroundings. This park is well-kept and has a ton of beautiful trees and bushes that surround the park.Dogs are welcome too! There is plenty of space for your pup to run around and play fetch!After a nice afternoon at South Park, head over to one of the cafes or restaurants around the perimeter!

South Sunset Playground has been recently renovated. It sports a brand new artificial turf field designed to hold two baseball diamonds and three U-10 soccer fields. There are two basketball courts, a tennis court, and a multi-use court. The playground has very bright colors. There is a clubhouse and restrooms available.

column3: Wunderlich Drive and Castle Glen Avenue

column9: Larry J. Marsalli Park's playground is located at the back of the park behind the parking lot and baseball diamond. The playground is dedicated for older kids and has a baseball theme to it. The play structure resides on sand and mulch. The playground also has tot swings, and possibly the more adventurous 2-5 yr olds could also play here. There are two sets of picnic tables that overlook the playground. Each set contains two picnic tables and 1 BBQs pit.the park also contains public restrooms.  The playground is partially fenced in, completely from the street with the opening only to the Parking lot, so kids can safely run free. One downside of this park is that it's located btw two major streets so it gets a little loud, but is completely safe due to the park being primarily fenced in.

Maywood Park is a large park that shares the grounds with an elementary school. In one corner there is a play structure dedicated for kids 2-5 and 5-12. They playground also contains a riding horse for tots as well as tot swings. The play area is located on sand and has some rubber for handicap accessibility. There are picnic tables that overlook the play structure and you can supervise the kids from here.The school itself has two play structures that can be used off school hours. These structures are dedicated for kids age 5-12 with an occasional slide that younger kids could use.The park also has public restrooms but they are further away from the play structures, a short walk away. The park has paved trails throughout which can be used for biking or stroller walks. Throughout the park, there a numerous picnic tables with personal bow pits.

Sunnyside Playground was renovated in 2007 and now offers kids and families a much-improved park and recreation center. There is a colorful play structure, a large sand area with fountain, and a fun merry go-round. There is also a tennis and basketball court, a large grass area for playing catch or frisbee, and dogs are welcome too! There are plenty of picnic tables and restrooms available on-site!

Located off Monarch Bay Drive near Fairway Drive, this 30-acre regional park that borders the beautiful San Leandro Shoreline. Amenities include picnic areas with barbecue grills, play apparatus, three newly renovated large group picnic areas, a large grassy area and a mile-long par course.

This small, one-acre park is located on Breed Avenue at Sunnyside Drive. The park has two backstops for playing baseball or softball, a barbecue pit and a picnic table. There is a fenced tot lot, which is shared by Washington School for use during recess and physical education classes.

column3: St Anthondy Dr. & St Phillip Ct.
Cres Village Cir & River Oaks Pkwy

column9: Originally dedicated in 1938, this is one of the City's oldest parks. It is located at the intersection of Bancroft and Callan avenues, across from Bancroft Middle School. San Leandro Creek runs along the north side of the park. The park features extensive sitting areas and picnic facilities and two separate play areas. There are five barbecue pits, 10 picnic tables and restroom facilities.

column3: Fox Ave. & N San Pedro St.

column9: This park has just been renovated and completed in June 2008. Upper Noe offers the neighborhood a brand new playground with a sand pit, an indoor gym, a baseball diamond and multipurpose field, basketball and tennis courts, and a recreation center with restrooms.

War Memorial Playground is a unique playground. It's an ant themed playground. The park is enclosed expect for the entrance. WMP is a small playground. They have a slide for the young kids, a challenging climbing structure for the older kids and a sand pit for tots. The picnic table is located in the center of the park to overlook the entire playground. There is a hill that separates the playground from the grass area where kids can run around. The park contains a parking lot and the public restrooms are right next to the playground.

Victoria Manalo Draves Park, a two acre park in SOMA, opened in October, 2006. It is located on Folsom Street between 6th and 7th streets. The park features a ball field, basketball court, bathrooms, a childrens' play area featuring a teepee-style jungle gym and a slide, a community garden, a landscaped area, picnic area, and play field.

Walter Haas Park and Playground was renovated in 2005 and became a spectacular neighborhood park that people of all ages may enjoy. This park has a little something for everyone: a basketball court, large grass area, dog park, and a two tier playground: one for toddlers and one for older children.
This downtown park is a great escape from the fast-paced atmosphere of the city. It has beautiful landscaping and a children's playground at the end of the park. There are restrooms available too.

column3: Robert Davey Jr Dr & Aughinbaugh Way

column9: Tucked into a residential, downtown neighborhood, this small park represents Lafayette’s first neighborhood park. It’s a popular spot for picnic lunches and draws families with young children due to its whimsical Pirate Ship that captures the imaginations of young children with a top deck, steering wheel, climbing ropes and port holes. The play equipment area has a low perimeter fence that keeps the children safely enclosed. In the back, beneath a shade structure, is a children’s picnic table and side serving table that can accommodate small parties. There are no restroom facilities and use of the facilities is on a first-come, first-served basis.

The 68-acre site of Lafayette Community Park contains a diverse array of topography, wildlife and recreation opportunities. The south-end has two sports fields that are used for baseball in the Spring and soccer in the Fall. There is a group picnic area that can be reserved and several single picnic tables. A Tot Playground with an adjoining lawn is near the picnic area and fields. A footbridge leads people from the parking lot, located at 480 Saint Mary’s Road, to the fields, picnic area and public restrooms.
This park offers barbecue pits, picnic tables, rentable equestrian facilities, hiking/biking/horseback riding trails, restrooms, horseshoe pits and a rentable dog area.

column3: Carson Pass Way & Fallen Leaf Dr

column9: Live Oak Manor Park is located off Gateway Drive, between Carlton Avenue and Lester Lane. A quiet neighborhood park with a playground, basketball court, picnic tables and large lawn areas.

(16 Acres) Center Avenue at Redwood Drive. Two lighted tennis courts, picnic areas, playground area, two ballfields, restrooms, bicycle/jogging paths,1-mile exercise course and a 2-mile pathway leading up to Hidden Lakes Park.

(2 Acres) Fig Tree Lane and Eastwoodbury. Neighborhood picnic area, playground area, multi-use field, bike racks and lighted pathways. All picnic areas are on a first come first serve basis. Click above for a map to this park.
(1.5 Acres) Vista Way and Pine Street. Adjacent to John Muir School, playground and multi-use field.

(150 Acres) North Court Street via Ferry Street. Four ballfield complex with concessions and restroom, soccer field, picnic areas, playground areas, horse- shoe pits and bocce ball courts, restroom, the Marina and fishing pier. Twelve- hundred seat amphitheater and skateboard park. Contact Recreation Services to reserve a picnic area (925)372-3510.

8.5 Acres, Pleasant Hill Road East and Church Street. Ballfield, basketball court, three lighted tennis courts, playground area, picnic areas and restrooms. Contact Recreation Services at (925) 372-3510 to reserve a picnic area.
(41 Acres) West end of Buckley Street. Swimming and diving complex, picnic areas,horseshoe pits, lighted softball field, restroom, playground area and gazebo.

column3: South Ashton, south of Millbrae Ave
column9: Rotary Park, situated on South Ashton just south of Millbrae Avenue is the perfect spot for children ages 2 to 5. Rotary Park offers smaller sized play equipment, a shaded picnic area, and a small grassy area. There is also a path for those who are looking to take a nice stroll or jog.

The Community Park is located next to the Orinda Community Center at 28 Orinda Way. The Park includes a large open grass area, two playground areas (one featuring a water play area), picnic and barbecue areas along with three tennis courts with lights. The gazebo, meadow, and tennis courts are available for reservation. The picnic area adjacent to the large tot lot is available on a first-come, first-serve basis.
Have audio but needed images

This 6.3 acre neighborhood park includes a picnic and barbeque area, surfaced court and children's play area. Visit this hidden gem! Great play structure, large grassy open area, and lots of shade trees. Rentals on weekends only; 30 person maximum capacity. Alcohol and Big Jumps are not permitted at this park.
Softball diamond, 3 reservable Picnic Areas, 2 open Picnic Areas, Basketball Court, 2 Children's Playgrounds and Community Gardens.Only open Monday - Friday 9am - 5pm.

The McKinley Playground is a colorful custom designed playground, which is based on East Sacramento’s 125 year old past.  It includes an “Alhambra Theater” entry archway, river boat, street trolley, the “Tower” bridge, large tree house, rubber surfacing with animal graphics, large climbing wall and boulders and concrete turtle. The playground was built on-site with over 2,000 community volunteers over a 6 day period, with substantial funding from community donations of money, building materials and equipment. The playground also features a custom seat wall and sand area with a tile mural installed by local Sacramento artists, and restoration of two original lion-fish painted by local Sacramento artist.

The playground is 16,800 s.f. and is located next to the pool facility and close to the restroom. The theme of the playground is "the solar system". Three distinct age appropriate play areas have been designed to include a rubber surfaced play area for infants under the age of 2, a tot lot for pre-school age children (2-5 years old), and an adventure play area for school age children (5-12 years old). Unique play features are included in the design to create a sensory enriched accessible playground. Such unique play elements in the play areas include an adventure play equipment with access ramps and handrails, a tot lot play equipment with access ramps and handrails, a merry-go-around, swings, spring riders, group rocking units, self propelled spin play units, independent climbing apparatuses and play units with sound features. Brightly colored protective rubber play surfacing in shapes of different planets also add to the space theme.

With 166.5 developed acres this regional park includes many amenities, including the Sacramento Zoo, Fairytale Town, Funderland, Picnic Areas for small events and large events, Wading Pool, Basketball Court, 6 Softball Field, Soccer Fields, Adventure Play Area, Lakes, Amphitheater, Rock Garden, Jogging Path, Village Green, Golf Course, Off-street Parking, Restrooms.

column3: Murphy Rd and Poppy Glen Rd

column9: Millennium Playground was built by 1,500 volunteers in May 2000 during a one week period. The playground was designed by the children of San Anselmo and incorporates San Anselmo themes, such as a train depot, seminary tower and Town Hall tower.

West Sunset Playground has a large soccer field, three baseball diamonds, two tennis courts, a full basketball court, three small basketball courts, a running track, a playground for kids, and a small recreation center.

This multi-level park built into the side of a hill contains two sand play areas, three game and sports areas, and a big community recreation center and indoor gym. The Rec center runs an after school program that helps kids with homework and offers snacks and activities.1 Basketball Court, Clubhouse/Activity Room, Kitchen, 2 Playgrounds, 4 Ping Pong Tables, Restrooms, 1 Tennis Court, 1 Volleyball Court.

Despite its small size, Woh Hei Yuen provides a variety of activities, attracting everyone from the elderly to small children. Views to and from the park's adjacent streets are kept open, while park structures and planting help to define sub areas and create a sense of depth. The principal landscape area has many features encouraging exploration, including a pavilion; wood bridge over a dry creek, stone walls, and granite boulders carved into human faces and oversized fruits. Concrete and special paving link the park's main activities, as well as providing spaces for uses such as tai chi and ball play.

column3: Townsend Park Cir at Gordy Dr

column9: The San Leandro Ball Park, located at Teagarden and Marina Boulevard, provides a major-league sized baseball facility used by hundreds of teams, from little leagues to semi-pro "Old Timers" leagues. The park is a fully-developed facility, complete with grandstands, restrooms, lighting, parking, concessions and scorebooth.

Located at the corner of Park Street and San Leandro Boulevard, provides open green space and recreational facilities for the neighborhoods surrounding it. There are two barbecue pits, four picnic tables, a baseball field, a basketball court, a play area and restrooms.

An important neighborhood park located on Wicks Boulevard at Elvina Drive. Over the years, four regulation ball fields have been developed here for organized baseball league play. There are also four barbecue pits, six picnic tables, a half court basketball court, restrooms and a concession booth.

Located at the intersection of Davis Street and Orchard Avenue, is the City's oldest park. Renovated in 1992, this community park has several unique features, including a lighted regulation softball field, a skateboard park, and a historical railway society building. In addition, the picnic areas, playground, and green space provide for neighborhood recreation needs. There are six barbecue pits, six picnic tables, a tot lot and restrooms.

Located on Bancroft Avenue at 145th Avenue. The park includes a variety of facilities not found in many other San Leandro parks, including bocce and horseshoe courts. There are also four barbecue pits, six picnic tables, a tiny tot area and restrooms.

column3: Corner Of Warden Avenue and Tudor Rd
column9: Warden Park is a small park that provides recreation amenities for nearby residents. It is located at the corner of Warden Avenue and Tudor Road. There are two barbecue pits, two picnic tables, a basketball court and a tot lot.

This 15-acre neighborhood park is located at 14900 Zelma, near Manor Boulevard. Its amenities include a new aquatic center with a variety of water features and a community room, tennis courts, barbecue pits, basketball courts, playground apparatuses, two softball areas and an open grassy field.

Fairway Glen Park's playground is dedicated for older kids. There are a number of slides and climbing walls. There is also a large field for kids to run and play as well as picnic tables overlooking the playground. Levi's stadium can be seen from the park.

column3: Canyon Del Rey Blvd. & Hilby Ave.

column9: Dan Foley is one of our principal parks in the GVRD system. It features a community center, fishing lake (state fishing laws enforced- see California Dept. of Fish and Game), natural grass baseball field (with lights), playground, and synthetic lighted soccer/ softball field.
Fun local park for the community.

Children's play areas, connection to walking trails, open turf area, picnic areas, swimming (May-September), tennis. Larkey Park is also home to the Lindsay Wildlife Museum and the Walnut Creek Model Railroad Society.
This is a very small park, near downtown Mountain View. This park is completely fenced in, has two small play structure for toddlers and a few picnic tables overlooking the play area.
Great neighborhood park, with lots of unique climbing structures.

Magic Bridge Playground is located within Meadow Park. It's enclosed and built primarily of rubber. The playground has an amphitheatre for story time. The park contains a number of sensory activities, a water feature, enclosed swings and climbing structures. There are also picnic tables within the playground. Just outside Magic Bridge Playground there are a number of play structures, picnic tables and BBQ pits that can be utilized after playtime is complete.
Arcturus Park offers 3/4 acre of playground area, small lawn area, and a tiny tot play area.

This beautiful 5.8 acre park offers a chance for a moonlight (or midday, for that matter!) stroll along the Lagoon with a view of downtown Foster City as a backdrop. Catamaran Park offers a large turf area, beach area, picnic area, basketball court, play apparatus, two lighted tennis courts, sand volleyball pit, and restroom facilities.
Edgewater Park is 9.5 acres with large lawn areas, lighted softball diamond, basketball courts, playgroundarea, and tennis courts.
Farragut Park offers a large lawn area, picnic tables, benches, small sand box, play apparatus, and restroom facilities.

Gull Park offers a sand beach and two playground areas, as well as swings, slides, a large lawn area, and restroom facilities. 3.1 acres.The picnic tables at Gull Park are reservable for groups of up to 50 people. Call (650) 286-3380 for more details.
Award winning Ketch Park features 1.6 acres of lawn, playground area, basketball court, and a gazebo suitable for a small picnic.

In a waterfront setting, Marlin Park's 3.1 acres offer a sand beach, playground area and large lawn area.The picnic tables at Marlin Park are reservable for groups of up to 50 people. Call (650)286-3380 for details.
Tucked into the southern-most point of Foster City, Port Royal Park offers 4 acres of soccer fields, restrooms, play apparatus, and walkways for a lovely afternoon stroll.

Play Ball!! Sea Cloud Park has been called the "sporting gem" of the Peninsula. It is the home of the Foster City Little League and offers more than 23 acres of baseball diamonds, soccer fields, lawn area, play apparatus, snack shack, batting cages, and restrooms.
Shad Park provides 2.1 acres of lawn area, playgrounds, basketball court, and a multi-purpose court.
With 2.4 acres, Sunfish Park offers playgrounds, a multi-purpose court and lawn area.
Turnstone Park offers a 1.5 acres of playground equipment, a lawn area, and a basketball court. There's also a sand pit for the kids to play in.
Howes Play Lot is located near Union Avenue,  between Thomas and Howes Drives, off Anne Way. It is only accessible from Thomas Drive and Howes Drive.
The play lot is located on the corner of Oak Park Drive and Garden Lane, off of Los Gatos Boulevard.A small neighborhood play lot with a playground and small lawn.

The Adventure Playground at the Berkeley Marina was opened in 1979. It is a wonderfully unique outdoor facility where staff encourage children to play and build creatively. Come climb on the many unusual kid designed and built forts, boats, and towers. Ride the zip line or hammer, saw, and paint. By providing these low risk activities Adventure Playground creates opportunities for children to learn cooperation, meet physical challenges and gain self confidence. Pictures of a fort building project.

Washington Park is the oldest park in Burlingame. The park is a year round center for community recreation. The Burlingame Recreation Division provides hundreds of classes and activities each year in the park and the Recreation Center. Tennis courts, a children’s playground, picnic areas, and baseball facilities are all in constant use.

The Olive Tot Lot is the smallest of all of the City's playgrounds, covering just a sliver of land in the shadow of Highway 101 off Olive Avenue. The site is packed with fun play equipment, including a "race track" and car wash for small trikes - perfect for younger children. There are two picnic tables and one barbecue grill under a wooden structure for shade. A four-seat permanent chess table is situated at the north end of the park, allowing play for older park-goers.

A historical site with large picnic areas (8 reservable sites) with BBQ's, open turf play areas, children's play equipment, a small lake and island with ducks and peacocks, off street parking and restrooms. A hiking trail provides access to the ridge of the Sulfur Springs Mountain for spectacular views of Vallejo and the Napa River.
This park at the center of town has a playground, gazebo and picnic tables. It can be reserved for private parties.

Roosevelt Park is located on Washington Street. The park has ample space and includes: a big kids play area, tots play area, an open field, skate park and community center. The big kids play area is located just off the major street and is partially fenced off from the street. There is a picnic area with a large BBQ pit, but this is located adjacent to the tot play area and skate park.

Westwood Oaks Park is a contains a small playground which is partially fenced in, completely on the street side. This park is dedicated for older kids, age 5-12, but also has little horses for tots to ride on. The park has a grass area for kids to run, and a path surrounding the park for riding your bike. The park also contains public bathrooms.

Live Oak Park is a small neighborhood park located next to Northside Branch Library. There are two play structures at the park, one for big kids and one for little kids. The paly area is made of sand with rubber making it handicap accessible. The park has 4 small picnic tables with individual BBQs that overlook the play structures. The restrooms are also located nearby so not a lot of traveling is required.

This small playground is action pack with three play structures. One for smaller kids age 2-5, with two slides and a sand pit. The other two play structures are for older kids, age 5-12 and are connected by monkey bars. Surfaces are primarily sand based with some rubber. The park is connected to two baseball fields and has a basketball court and tennis court attached.
